attributes.description: The royal saint whose penance brought the river Gangá from heaven to earth to liberate the sons of Sagar.
The holy river known as Tripathagá (three-pathed) who purifies sin and flows through heaven, earth, and hell.
The deity who received Gangá on his head and quaffed the Halahala poison during the churning of the sea.
A saint who drank the Gangá in anger but later released her through his ears, becoming her symbolic father.
The ancient king whose sixty thousand sons were reduced to ashes and later liberated by Gangá's water.
The Creator who grants the boon of Gangá's descent to Bhagírath and names her Bhágirathí.
The Preserver who assumed a tortoise form to support Mount Mandar during the churning of the milky sea.
The Thousand-eyed King of Gods who cleaved Diti's unborn child and cursed Ahalyá's seducer (himself) and was cursed by Gautam.
Wife of Ka[yap and mother of the Titans who performed penance to birth a son capable of slaying Indra.
Wife of Ka[yap and mother of the Gods (Suras).
The nectar of immortality produced by churning the milky sea.
Storm gods born from the seven pieces of Diti's bud, destined to rule the sky.
The wife of Gautam who was cursed to remain invisible and subsist on air until Ráma's arrival.
A powerful ascetic who cursed both Indra and his wife Ahalyá for their betrayal.
A beautiful city built by King Vi[ála, compared to heaven itself.
The cosmic ocean churned by Gods and Titans to obtain the Amrit.

attributes.context: Bhagírath led the river Gangá's descent to the sea and nether caves.
Gangá is called Jáhnavi because she was released from Jahnu's ear.
Ziva's touch sanctified the tide of the Gangá.
VishGu took the form of a tortoise to support the mountain during the churning.
Indra cleaved the bud from which the seven Maruts were born.
Gautam is the husband of Ahalyá who cursed her to solitude.
Indra assumed the form of Gautam to seduce Ahalyá.
Ráma is the destined guest whose presence removes Ahalyá's stain and curse.
